title: How many MLB players will have a regular season batting average of .400 or higher in 2020?
preds: Only five days left in the 'regular' season
Unlikely to bat over .500 for the remainder of the season.

Quick, rough estimates for the two players batting closest to .400 right now: Tim Anderson and DJ LeMahieu
(https://www.espn.com/mlb/stats/player) - Both players' teams have 11 scheduled games left this season. - Anderson currently has 62 hits in 166 official at-bats. Estimating approx. 40 more official at-bats over his final 11 games, he would need at least 21 more hits to reach/exceed .400. (83 total hits divided by 206 total, projected at-bats = .403 average.) - LeMahieu currently has 56 hits in 150 at-bats. He would need at least 20 more hits over his last 40 projected at-bats to reach .400. (76 total hits divided by 190 projected at-bats = .400) Other scenarios are possible, e.g.: Players getting a few more walks, requiring slightly fewer hits to reach .400. 
However, in the estimate above both players will need to bat at least .500 over their last 11 games to reach a .400 average for the season. Seems unlikely.

While the Yankees have played 27 games, LeMahieu has only had 73 at bats, putting him below the 3.1 plate appearances per team game requirement. If he does not bat more than he will not meet the requirement, if he does then his average will almost definitely fall. If the season reaches its projected 60 games, he will need 113 more bats, or 3.42 at bats each game. This is doable but with such a quick succession of games it will be difficult to make every plate appearance remaining count. Blackmon has 107 at bats, putting him well above the threshold of 3.1 plate appearances per team game thus far, but his average has taken a hit (no pun intended) in recent weeks. Long story short, unless the season ends tomorrow, I'm sticking with my original prediction which is turning into more and more conservative an estimate every week.

Using an average batting average league-wide of 0.266 and the standard deviation determined for the 2017 season (0.027), a statistical analysis yields a probability of 3.818e-05% per player (assuming a normal distribution). With this, we can calculate the odds that all 877 (or thereabouts) players in the MLB miss this mark to be 99.97%. 
That assumes a full season and a normalized distribution of batting prowess, which are large assumptions given the current landscape. However, even if we assume current conditions make it 100% more likely for a player to reach this threshold, that gives a 3% possibility one player does it and a 0.09% chance two do. This is an extreme assumption, but is relatively reflective of the current state of things across the league. As things continue, projections should regress more and more towards the 0.03% chance predicted by statistical models, as there is no indication that this season is an outlier in any way other than the duration.

As of this morning (Aug 11), three players are hitting .400 or better and three more .350 or better. Most of this probability rests with Charlie Blackmon. He's hitting .500. The ZiPS projection system figures he's a .337 hitter in the long run. Assuming he has about 150 AB left in his season (playing about 40 more games), and attaching a rough distribution around the point estate of his true talent, I think he has about a 20.5% chance. Applying the same to Donovan Solano and DJ Lemahieu (both ~.310 hitters), I get a 1% chance and a 0.4% chance, respectively. Daniel Murphy, Kyle Lewis, and Starling Matter, all worse hitters for average who would also need to hit >.400 the rest of the way, clock in around 0.1%. I'll add 0.5% for the field. That all adds up to about 23%. The odds of more than one guy doing it are less than 1%.
I also have to account for the probability that one of these teams plays far less than their remaining 40ish games due to COVID. Over about 30 games, their odds increase about 50%. If there's a 15% chance that a given team gets hit and misses an average of 10 games, Blackmon's odds in particular increase by about 3%. The rest are too small for the marginal change to really matter.

A lot of really interesting write-ups about this on fangraphs. I'm going off of their work as it seems like very astute statistical analysis.  The first assumes a player's batting average is their true batting average and estimates the probability a player hits above .400 for a full season and for a 60 game season. They find that there is about a 3% chance of any player hitting over .400 for a 60 game season. [1]  The second follows a similar procedure but is less stringent on their assumptions about a players "true batting average." As a result, they get around a 9.5% chance of someone hitting over .400 for the season. [2] From those it seems like any estimate from 90-99% for the 0 category seems pretty reasonable. The only thing that I'd like to add to their analysis is that this season could end up being shorter than 60 games. If the season ended up being only 30 games would this question still be valid? If so, it seems that we should increase our estimate for the non zero categories.  For example, Charlie Blackmon is hitting .484 through 16 games and if the season cancels soon (or the Rockies get hit with many coronavirus cases) it seems possible that he would end up over .400.  [1] https://blogs.fangraphs.com/will-a-player-hit-400-this-season/
[2] https://blogs.fangraphs.com/toppling-ted-the-60-game-season-and-the-400-batting-average/
